newsitem.title: UK: EMI leaps on bid talk, NatWest recomendation.
newsitem.headline: EMI leaps on bid talk, NatWest recomendation.

text.p: Share in music publisher EMI Group Plc rose on Friday as a recent NatWest recommendation continued to buoy the stock and bid speculation revived, helping catch some market-makers short of stock, traders said.
The stock was up 33p at 13.42-1/2 stg by 1135 GMT, continuing a rebound since it touched a post-demerger low of 11.83 stg on November 6.
Traders said NatWest had set a price target of 15.00 stg on the stock, and said vague market rumours had pointed to Microsoft Corp as a possible bidder for the UK firm.
Others said the stock had been squeezed higher amid a shortage of stock in the market.
"It's all one-way, the trouble is you can't find any sellers when the price is going up," said one senior sales trader.
Shares in EMI, which spun off its retail arm Thorn earlier this year, came under pressure in recent weeks amid reports of weak music sales and as rival PolyGram issued a profit warning.

Yet a Financial Times report last week said industry figures showed UK music sales were on the rise in the latest quarter, and EMI could also gain from a strong Christmas season -- its most important time of the year for sales.
Trading volume in the stock was a modest 444,797 shares.
No-one at EMI was immediately available for comment on the latest bid speculation.
